head.title: Fighting an Overpowering Urge To Have It Out With the Referee

hedline.hl1: Fighting an Overpowering Urge To Have It Out With the Referee

abstract.p: Steven Greenhouse, coach of youth league soccer team, recalls tie game that strained his sportsmanship when referee made string of perplexing, unfavorable calls; drawing (M)

block.p: ADMITTEDLY I was already in a paranoid frame of mind when the referee blew the opening whistle for my team's soccer game against Yonkers. Two starters on the team I coach -- a team of 11-year-old boys from Pelham -- arrived just 30 seconds before the game, and they were late for a maddening reason: the directions our opponents gave us had a serious error.
The directions told us to get off the Saw Mill River Parkway and make a left on Prospect Street. Unfortunately, there was no Prospect Street.

ADMITTEDLY I was already in a paranoid frame of mind when the referee blew the opening whistle for my team's soccer game against Yonkers. Two starters on the team I coach -- a team of 11-year-old boys from Pelham -- arrived just 30 seconds before the game, and they were late for a maddening reason: the directions our opponents gave us had a serious error.
The directions told us to get off the Saw Mill River Parkway and make a left on Prospect Street. Unfortunately, there was no Prospect Street.

I was assured that the poor directions were an innocent mistake. But a voice in my head whispered that maybe the mistake was intentional, aimed at throwing my team off balance. Still, I did not dare articulate that thought to the Yonkers coach for fear of seeming unsportsmanlike.
In our genteel suburban soccer league, which emphasizes teaching sportsmanship, many parents consider it far worse to be unsportsmanlike than to lose a game.
My sportsmanship was severely tested 20 minutes into the game when our left wing, Alex, slipped a shot past the Yonkers goalie.

That put us ahead 1-0, or so I thought. But a few seconds later, the referee declared Alex off-side and canceled the goal. (An offensive player is off-side when he or she is ahead of the ball and there are not at least two defensive players closer to the goal.)

The referee's call perplexed me. Just before Alex scored, Sam, our center fullback, had drilled a free kick so hard that it bounced out of the Yonkers goalie's hands. Alex then swooped in and kicked the ball into the goal. I questioned the off-side call because Alex was behind the ball, not ahead of it, when it came his way.
Although I was boiling inside, I kept my mouth shut.

I remembered the advice on the soccer league's Web site: ''NEVER CRITICIZE THE REFEREE.'' Yes, it was in all capitals. Explaining that the league was having a hard time finding enough refs, the Web site warned that raining criticism on refs would make even fewer people want the job.
Early in the second half, several other developments stoked my paranoia and strained my sportsmanship.

A Yonkers halfback kicked a ball that was snaking out of bounds near our goal, and my son Jeremy, a fullback, let it go out, convinced we would have a goal kick. But the referee awarded Yonkers a corner kick. I was shocked, but again I kept quiet.

Minutes later, a nearly identical episode occurred. A Yonkers linesman kicked a shot that went out of bounds, and Sam, our center fullback, patiently watched the ball, expecting to be given a goal kick. Instead, the referee awarded our opponents a corner kick. I couldn't believe it.

By now, I was thinking that maybe the ref did have something against us. Maybe, out of class solidarity, the ref was pulling for blue-collar Yonkers over pampered Pelham. Maybe he had second cousins living in Yonkers.

About 40 minutes into the game, the Yonkers left wing crossed the ball perfectly, and their center forward hammered a shot that just missed our goal. ''Nice play,'' I told myself. ''We dodged a bullet.'' But the ref signaled that Yonkers was to have a penalty kick. All the Pelham parents were dumbfounded because none of us had seen a foul.

I was upset because I understood that refs shouldn't award a penalty kick that could decide a close game unless there was a blatant foul. And certainly whatever happened did not impede Yonkers's play.
But again, wanting to display sportsmanship, I didn't yell at the ref. My good behavior went unrewarded, however. Yonkers made the penalty kick, putting them ahead, 1-0.

I couldn't believe we were going to lose this way. With eight minutes left, I saw our star center forward, Michael, sprawled on the ground, crying, hurt by an opponent who had accidentally kneed him in the chest. After a few minutes, Michael gathered himself and was ready to resume play.
Ninety seconds later, Michael, clearly angry, rocketed in a shot that tied the game, 1-1. That was the final score in a game that I thought we should have won, 2-0.

The game over, I diplomatically approached the ref to ask why he had given Yonkers the penalty kick. He said one of our fullbacks had elbowed a Yonkers player in the back. Dissatisfied, I said none of my team's parents had seen anything.

Having tried to be a paragon of sportsmanship, I feared that the boys on my team might conclude that I was a wimp for not standing up for them. They had battled for 60 minutes on the field, and they might understandably wonder why their coach was not battling more for them.

So I told the boys in no uncertain terms that I thought the ref was wrong to call back our goal and to award Yonkers a penalty kick. As for life's lessons, I could only offer them cliches like, ''Life is sometimes unfair,'' and ''It's only a game.''
I, of course, congratulated the team for showing grit, for eking out a tie in the face of a string of perplexing, unfavorable calls.
While driving home, I told my son Jeremy I had no idea why the ref seemed to be tilting against us.
''He wasn't tilting against us,'' Jeremy said. ''He was just a bad ref.''
Maybe, I realized, my 11-year-old has more sense than I do.
SOCCER DAD
